titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: A wet gloomy day from morning to nightfall: that inveterate editor of joint–potboilers, Sir James Marchant, is moved by my letters in the

to propose that I should co–operate in a series of Books on moral Theology, or, at least, in a volume. But I have no belief in these blendings of piety & business, and no particular fondness for Sir J.M. as bear–leader, so I declined.
writes to me at some length in reply to my inquiry about Wynyard:

"The disastrous coal strike & coal position has crippled my plans for the future, & I am bound to take cognizance of it, more for Robin's sake & the sake of the business than my own, because I can manage but of course, on a different scale without my coal interest at all."
treatment of Alnwick, & vacate it for 3 years. I am very sorry, and disappointed for in Ireland I took the impression that Lord L. meant to live more regularly at Wynyard.
came to see me during the afternoon, & had tea. Ella took Miss Haldane to see Raby Castle.
With ourselves the party numbered 12 persons. I wrote to Peter Richardson.
